scenes.location: Verona. An open place

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Cease to persuade, my loving Proteus. Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits. Were't not affection chains thy tender days To the sweet glances of thy honoured love, I rather would entreat thy company To see the wonders of the world abroad Than, living dully sluggardized at home, Wear out thy youth with shapeless idleness. But since thou lov'st, love still, and thrive therein, Even as I would when I to love begin.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Wilt thou be gone? Sweet Valentine, adieu. Think on thy Proteus when thou haply seest Some rare noteworthy object in thy travel. Wish me partaker in thy happiness When thou dost meet good hap; and in thy danger, If ever danger do environ thee, Commend thy grievance to my holy prayers, For I will be thy headsman, Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: And on a love-book pray for my success?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Upon some book I love I'll pray for thee.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: That's on some shallow story of deep love, How young Leander crossed the Hellespont.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: That's a deep story of a deeper love, For he was more than over shoes in love.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: 'Tis true; for you are over boots in love, And yet you never swam the Hellespont.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Over the boots? Nay, give me not the boots.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: No, I will not, for it boots thee not.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: What?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: To be in love, where scorn is bought with groans, Coy looks with heart-sore sighs, one fading moment's mirth With twenty watchful, weary, tedious nights. If haply won, perhaps a hapless gain; If lost, why then a grievous labour won; However, but a folly bought with wit, Or else a wit by folly vanquished.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: So, by your circumstance, you call me fool.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: So, by your circumstance, I fear you'll prove.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: 'Tis love you cavil at. I am not Love.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Love is your master, for he masters you; And he that is so yoked by a fool Methinks should not be chronicled for wise.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Yet writers say, as in the sweetest bud The eating canker dwells, so eating love Inhabits in the finest wits of all.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: And writers say, as the most forward bud Is eaten by the canker ere it blow, Even so by love the young and tender wit Is turned to folly, blasting in the bud, Losing his verdure even in the prime, And all the fair effects of future hopes. But wherefore waste I time to counsel thee That art a votary to fond desire? Once more adieu. My father at the road Expects my coming, there to see me shipped.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: And thither will I bring thee, Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Sweet Proteus, no. Now let us take our leave. To Milan let me hear from thee by letters Of thy success in love, and what news else Betideth here in absence of thy friend; And I likewise will visit thee with mine.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: All happiness bechance to thee in Milan.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: As much to you at home, and so farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: He after honour hunts, I after love. He leaves his friends to dignify them more; I leave myself, my friends, and all for love. Thou, Julia, thou hast metamorphosed me, Made me neglect my studies, lose my time, War with good counsel, set the world at nought; Made wit with musing weak, heart sick with thought.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Sir Proteus, 'save you. Saw you my master?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: But now he parted hence to embark for Milan.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Twenty to one, then, he is shipped already, And I have played the sheep in losing him.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Indeed a sheep doth very often stray, An if the shepherd be a while away.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: You conclude that my master is a shepherd then, and I a sheep?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Why then, my horns are his horns, whether I wake or sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: A silly answer, and fitting well a sheep.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: This proves me still a sheep.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: True, and thy master a shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Nay, that I can deny by a circumstance.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: It shall go hard but I'll prove it by another.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: The shepherd seeks the sheep, and not the sheep the shepherd; but I seek my master, and my master seeks not me. Therefore I am no sheep.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: The sheep for fodder follow the shepherd; the shepherd for food follows not the sheep. Thou for wages followest thy master; thy master for wages follows not thee. Therefore thou art a sheep.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Such another proof will make me cry "baa".

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: But dost thou hear? Gav'st thou my letter to Julia?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Ay, sir. I, a lost mutton, gave your letter to her, a laced mutton, and she, a laced mutton, gave me, a lost mutton, nothing for my labour.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Here's too small a pasture for such store of muttons.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: If the ground be overcharged, you were best stick her.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Nay, in that you are astray; 'twere best pound you.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Nay, sir, less than a pound shall serve me for carrying your letter.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: You mistake; I mean the pound, a pinfold.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: From a pound to a pin? Fold it over and over, 'Tis threefold too little for carrying a letter to your lover.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: But what said she?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Ay.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Nod-"Ay". Why, that's "noddy".

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: You mistook, sir. I say she did nod, and you ask me if she did nod; and I say "Ay".

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: And that set together is "noddy".

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Now you have taken the pains to set it together, take it for your pains.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: No, no, you shall have it for bearing the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Well, I perceive I must be fain to bear with you.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Why, sir, how do you bear with me?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, the letter, very orderly, having nothing but the word "noddy" for my pains.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Beshrew me, but you have a quick wit.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: And yet it cannot overtake your slow purse.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Come, come, open the matter; in brief, what said she?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Open your purse, that the money and the matter may be both at once delivered.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Well, sir, here is for your pains. What said she?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Truly, sir, I think you'll hardly win her.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Why? Couldst thou perceive so much from her?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Sir, I could perceive nothing at all from her; no, not so much as a ducat for delivering your letter. And being so hard to me that brought your mind, I fear she'll prove as hard to you in telling your mind. Give her no token but stones, for she's as hard as steel.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: What said she, nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: No, not so much as "Take this for thy pains." To testify your bounty, I thank you, you have testerned me; in requital whereof, henceforth carry your letters yourself. And so, sir, I'll commend you to my master.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Go, go, begone, to save your ship from wrack, Which cannot perish having thee aboard, Being destined to a drier death on shore. I must go send some better messenger. I fear my Julia would not deign my lines, Receiving them from such a worthless post.

scenes.location: The same. The garden of Julia's house

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: But say, Lucetta, now we are alone, Wouldst thou then counsel me to fall in love?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Ay, madam, so you stumble not unheedfully.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Of all the fair resort of gentlemen That every day with parle encounter me, In thy opinion which is worthiest love?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Please you, repeat their names, I'll show my mind According to my shallow simple skill.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: What think'st thou of the fair Sir Eglamour?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: As of a knight well-spoken, neat, and fine; But, were I you, he never should be mine.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: What think'st thou of the rich Mercatio?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Well of his wealth; but of himself, so-so.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: What think'st thou of the gentle Proteus?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Lord, Lord, to see what folly reigns in us!

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: How now? What means this passion at his name?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Pardon, dear madam, 'tis a passing shame That I, unworthy body as I am, Should censure thus on lovely gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Why not on Proteus, as of all the rest?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Then thus: of many good I think him best.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Your reason?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: I have no other but a woman's reason: I think him so because I think him so.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: And wouldst thou have me cast my love on him?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Ay, if you thought your love not cast away.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Why, he of all the rest hath never moved me.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Yet he of all the rest I think best loves ye.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: His little speaking shows his love but small.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Fire that's closest kept burns most of all.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: They do not love that do not show their love.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: O, they love least that let men know their love.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: I would I knew his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Peruse this paper, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: _To Julia_-Say, from whom?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: That the contents will show.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Say, say, who gave it thee?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Sir Valentine's page, and sent, I think, from Proteus. He would have given it you, but I, being in the way, Did in your name receive it. Pardon the fault, I pray.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Now, by my modesty, a goodly broker! Dare you presume to harbour wanton lines? To whisper and conspire against my youth? Now trust me, 'tis an office of great worth, And you an officer fit for the place. There, take the paper; see it be returned, Or else return no more into my sight.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: To plead for love deserves more fee than hate.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Will ye be gone?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: That you may ruminate.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: And yet I would I had o'erlooked the letter. It were a shame to call her back again And pray her to a fault for which I chid her. What fool is she, that knows I am a maid And would not force the letter to my view, Since maids in modesty say "No" to that Which they would have the profferer construe "Ay". Fie, fie, how wayward is this foolish love That like a testy babe will scratch the nurse And presently, all humbled, kiss the rod! How churlishly I chid Lucetta hence, When willingly I would have had her here! How angerly I taught my brow to frown, When inward joy enforced my heart to smile! My penance is to call Lucetta back And ask remission for my folly past. What ho! Lucetta!

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: What would your ladyship?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Is 't near dinner time?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: I would it were, That you might kill your stomach on your meat And not upon your maid.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: What is't that you took up so gingerly?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Why didst thou stoop, then?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: To take a paper up that I let fall.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: And is that paper nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Nothing concerning me.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Then let it lie for those that it concerns.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Madam, it will not lie where it concerns, Unless it have a false interpreter.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Some love of yours hath writ to you in rhyme.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: That I might sing it, madam, to a tune. Give me a note. Your ladyship can set-

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: As little by such toys as may be possible. Best sing it to the tune of "Light o' Love".

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: It is too heavy for so light a tune.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Heavy? Belike it hath some burden then?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Ay, and melodious were it, would you sing it.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: And why not you?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: I cannot reach so high.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Let's see your song.  How now, minion!

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Keep tune there still, so you will sing it out. And yet methinks I do not like this tune.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: You do not?

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: No, madam, it is too sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: You, minion, are too saucy.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Nay, now you are too flat And mar the concord with too harsh a descant. There wanteth but a mean to fill your song.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: The mean is drowned with your unruly bass.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Indeed, I bid the base for Proteus.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: This babble shall not henceforth trouble me. Here is a coil with protestation!  Go, get you gone, and let the papers lie. You would be fingering them to anger me.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: She makes it strange, but she would be best pleased To be so angered with another letter.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Nay, would I were so angered with the same! O hateful hands, to tear such loving words! Injurious wasps, to feed on such sweet honey And kill the bees that yield it with your stings! I'll kiss each several paper for amends. Look, here is writ _kind Julia_. Unkind Julia! As in revenge of thy ingratitude, I throw thy name against the bruising stones, Trampling contemptuously on thy disdain. And here is writ _love-wounded Proteus_. Poor wounded name, my bosom as a bed Shall lodge thee till thy wound be throughly healed; And thus I search it with a sovereign kiss. But twice or thrice was _Proteus_ written down. Be calm, good wind, blow not a word away Till I have found each letter in the letter Except mine own name. That some whirlwind bear Unto a ragged, fearful, hanging rock, And throw it thence into the raging sea. Lo, here in one line is his name twice writ: _Poor forlorn Proteus, passionate Proteus, To the sweet Julia._ That I'll tear away; And yet I will not, sith so prettily He couples it to his complaining names. Thus will I fold them one upon another. Now kiss, embrace, contend, do what you will.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Madam, dinner is ready, and your father stays.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Well, let us go.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: What, shall these papers lie like tell-tales here?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: If you respect them, best to take them up.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Nay, I was taken up for laying them down. Yet here they shall not lie, for catching cold.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: I see you have a month's mind to them.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Ay, madam, you may say what sights you see; I see things too, although you judge I wink.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Come, come, will't please you go?

scenes.location: The same. A room in Antonio's house

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Tell me, Pantino, what sad talk was that Wherewith my brother held you in the cloister?

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: 'Twas of his nephew Proteus, your son.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Why, what of him?

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: He wondered that your lordship Would suffer him to spend his youth at home While other men, of slender reputation, Put forth their sons to seek preferment out: Some to the wars to try their fortune there; Some to discover islands far away; Some to the studious universities. For any or for all these exercises He said that Proteus your son was meet, And did request me to importune you To let him spend his time no more at home, Which would be great impeachment to his age In having known no travel in his youth.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Nor need'st thou much importune me to that Whereon this month I have been hammering. I have considered well his loss of time, And how he cannot be a perfect man, Not being tried and tutored in the world. Experience is by industry achieved And perfected by the swift course of time. Then tell me whither were I best to send him?

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: I think your lordship is not ignorant How his companion, youthful Valentine, Attends the Emperor in his royal court.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: I know it well.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: 'Twere good, I think, your lordship sent him thither. There shall he practise tilts and tournaments, Hear sweet discourse, converse with noblemen, And be in eye of every exercise Worthy his youth and nobleness of birth.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: I like thy counsel; well hast thou advised, And that thou mayst perceive how well I like it, The execution of it shall make known. Even with the speediest expedition I will dispatch him to the Emperor's court.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: Tomorrow, may it please you, Don Alphonso With other gentlemen of good esteem Are journeying to salute the Emperor And to commend their service to his will.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Good company. With them shall Proteus go. And in good time! Now will we break with him.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Sweet love, sweet lines, sweet life! Here is her hand, the agent of her heart; Here is her oath for love, her honour's pawn. O, that our fathers would applaud our loves To seal our happiness with their consents. O heavenly Julia!

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: How now? What letter are you reading there?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: May't please your lordship, 'tis a word or two Of commendations sent from Valentine, Delivered by a friend that came from him.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Lend me the letter. Let me see what news.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: There is no news, my lord, but that he writes How happily he lives, how well beloved And daily graced by the Emperor, Wishing me with him, partner of his fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: And how stand you affected to his wish?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: As one relying on your lordship's will, And not depending on his friendly wish.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: My will is something sorted with his wish. Muse not that I thus suddenly proceed, For what I will, I will, and there an end. I am resolved that thou shalt spend some time With Valentinus in the Emperor's court. What maintenance he from his friends receives, Like exhibition thou shalt have from me. Tomorrow be in readiness to go. Excuse it not, for I am peremptory.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: My lord, I cannot be so soon provided; Please you deliberate a day or two.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Look what thou want'st shall be sent after thee. No more of stay. Tomorrow thou must go. Come on, Pantino, you shall be employed To hasten on his expedition.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Thus have I shunned the fire for fear of burning And drenched me in the sea, where I am drowned. I feared to show my father Julia's letter Lest he should take exceptions to my love, And with the vantage of mine own excuse Hath he excepted most against my love. O, how this spring of love resembleth The uncertain glory of an April day, Which now shows all the beauty of the sun, And by an by a cloud takes all away.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: Sir Proteus, your father calls for you. He is in haste. Therefore, I pray you, go.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Why, this it is: my heart accords thereto, And yet a thousand times it answers "No".

scenes.location: Milan. A room in the Duke's palace

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Sir, your glove.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Not mine. My gloves are on.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Why, then, this may be yours, for this is but one.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Ha? Let me see. Ay, give it me, it's mine. Sweet ornament that decks a thing divine! Ah, Silvia, Silvia!

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Madam Silvia! Madam Silvia!

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: How now, sirrah?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: She is not within hearing, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Why, sir, who bade you call her?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Your worship, sir, or else I mistook.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Well, you'll still be too forward.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: And yet I was last chidden for being too slow.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Go to, sir. Tell me, do you know Madam Silvia?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: She that your worship loves?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Why, how know you that I am in love?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Marry, by these special marks: first, you have learned, like Sir Proteus, to wreathe your arms like a malcontent; to relish a love-song, like a robin redbreast; to walk alone, like one that had the pestilence; to sigh, like a schoolboy that had lost his ABC; to weep, like a young wench that had buried her grandam; to fast, like one that takes diet; to watch, like one that fears robbing; to speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas. You were wont, when you laughed, to crow like a cock; when you walked, to walk like one of the lions; when you fasted, it was presently after dinner; when you looked sadly, it was for want of money. And now you are metamorphosed with a mistress, that, when I look on you, I can hardly think you my master.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Are all these things perceived in me?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: They are all perceived without ye.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Without me? They cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Without you? Nay, that's certain, for without you were so simple, none else would. But you are so without these follies, that these follies are within you, and shine through you like the water in an urinal, that not an eye that sees you but is a physician to comment on your malady.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: But tell me, dost thou know my lady Silvia?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: She that you gaze on so as she sits at supper?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Hast thou observed that? Even she I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Why, sir, I know her not.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Dost thou know her by my gazing on her, and yet know'st her not?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Is she not hard-favoured, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Not so fair, boy, as well-favoured.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Sir, I know that well enough.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: What dost thou know?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: That she is not so fair as, of you, well-favoured.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I mean that her beauty is exquisite but her favour infinite.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: That's because the one is painted, and the other out of all count.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: How painted? And how out of count?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, so painted to make her fair, that no man counts of her beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: How esteem'st thou me? I account of her beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: You never saw her since she was deformed.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: How long hath she been deformed?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Ever since you loved her.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I have loved her ever since I saw her, and still I see her beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: If you love her, you cannot see her.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Because Love is blind. O, that you had mine eyes, or your own eyes had the lights they were wont to have when you chid at Sir Proteus for going ungartered!

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: What should I see then?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Your own present folly and her passing deformity; for he, being in love, could not see to garter his hose; and you, being in love, cannot see to put on your hose.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Belike, boy, then you are in love, for last morning you could not see to wipe my shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: True, sir, I was in love with my bed. I thank you, you swinged me for my love, which makes me the bolder to chide you for yours.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: In conclusion, I stand affected to her.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: I would you were set, so your affection would cease.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Last night she enjoined me to write some lines to one she loves.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: And have you?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I have.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Are they not lamely writ?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: No, boy, but as well as I can do them. Peace, here she comes.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: O excellent motion! O exceeding puppet! Now will he interpret to her.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Madam and mistress, a thousand good-morrows.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: O, give ye good e'en! Here's a million of manners.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Sir Valentine and servant, to you two thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: He should give her interest, and she gives it him.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: As you enjoined me, I have writ your letter Unto the secret nameless friend of yours, Which I was much unwilling to proceed in But for my duty to your ladyship.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: I thank you, gentle servant, 'tis very clerkly done.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Now trust me, madam, it came hardly off, For, being ignorant to whom it goes, I writ at random, very doubtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Perchance you think too much of so much pains?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: No, madam; so it stead you, I will write, Please you command, a thousand times as much. And yet-

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: A pretty period. Well, I guess the sequel; And yet I will not name it. And yet I care not. And yet take this again. And yet I thank you, Meaning henceforth to trouble you no more.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: And yet you will; and yet another "yet".

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: What means your ladyship? Do you not like it?

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Yes, yes, the lines are very quaintly writ, But, since unwillingly, take them again. Nay, take them.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Madam, they are for you.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Ay, ay, you writ them, sir, at my request, But I will none of them. They are for you. I would have had them writ more movingly.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Please you, I'll write your ladyship another.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: And when it's writ, for my sake read it over, And if it please you, so; if not, why, so.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: If it please me, madam? What then?

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Why, if it please you, take it for your labour. And so good morrow, servant.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: O jest unseen, inscrutable, invisible, As a nose on a man's face, or a weathercock on a steeple! My master sues to her, and she hath taught her suitor, He being her pupil, to become her tutor. O excellent device! Was there ever heard a better? That my master, being scribe, to himself should write the letter?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: How now, sir? What are you reasoning with yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Nay, I was rhyming. 'Tis you that have the reason.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: To be a spokesman from Madam Silvia.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: To whom?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: To yourself. Why, she woos you by a figure.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: What figure?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: By a letter, I should say.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Why, she hath not writ to me.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: What need she, when she hath made you write to yourself? Why, do you not perceive the jest?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: No, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: No believing you indeed, sir. But did you perceive her earnest?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: She gave me none, except an angry word.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Why, she hath given you a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: That's the letter I writ to her friend.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: And that letter hath she delivered, and there an end.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I would it were no worse.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: I'll warrant you, 'tis as well. For often have you writ to her, and she, in modesty Or else for want of idle time, could not again reply, Or fearing else some messenger that might her mind discover, Herself hath taught her love himself to write unto her lover. All this I speak in print, for in print I found it. Why muse you, sir? 'Tis dinner time.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I have dined.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Ay, but hearken, sir, though the chameleon Love can feed on the air, I am one that am nourished by my victuals, and would fain have meat. O, be not like your mistress! Be moved, be moved.

scenes.location: Verona. A room in Julia's house

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Have patience, gentle Julia.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: I must, where is no remedy.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: When possibly I can, I will return.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: If you turn not, you will return the sooner. Keep this remembrance for thy Julia's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Why, then we'll make exchange. Here, take you this.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: And seal the bargain with a holy kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Here is my hand for my true constancy. And when that hour o'erslips me in the day Wherein I sigh not, Julia, for thy sake, The next ensuing hour some foul mischance Torment me for my love's forgetfulness. My father stays my coming; answer not. The tide is now-nay, not thy tide of tears, That tide will stay me longer than I should. Julia, farewell. What, gone without a word? Ay, so true love should do. It cannot speak, For truth hath better deeds than words to grace it.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: Sir Proteus, you are stayed for.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Go, I come, I come. Alas, this parting strikes poor lovers dumb.

scenes.location: The same. A street

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Nay, 'twill be this hour ere I have done weeping; all the kind of the Lances have this very fault. I have received my proportion, like the prodigious son, and am going with Sir Proteus to the Imperial's court. I think Crab my dog be the sourest-natured dog that lives: my mother weeping, my father wailing, my sister crying, our maid howling, our cat wringing her hands, and all our house in a great perplexity, yet did not this cruel-hearted cur shed one tear. He is a stone, a very pebblestone, and has no more pity in him than a dog. A Jew would have wept to have seen our parting. Why, my grandam, having no eyes, look you, wept herself blind at my parting. Nay, I'll show you the manner of it. This shoe is my father. No, this left shoe is my father; no, no, this left shoe is my mother. Nay, that cannot be so neither. Yes, it is so, it is so; it hath the worser sole. This shoe with the hole in it is my mother, and this my father. A vengeance on 't, there 'tis. Now, sir, this staff is my sister, for, look you, she is as white as a lily and as small as a wand. This hat is Nan, our maid. I am the dog. No, the dog is himself, and I am the dog. O, the dog is me, and I am myself. Ay, so, so. Now come I to my father: "Father, your blessing." Now should not the shoe speak a word for weeping. Now should I kiss my father. Well, he weeps on. Now come I to my mother. O, that she could speak now like a wood woman! Well, I kiss her. Why there 'tis; here's my mother's breath up and down. Now come I to my sister. Mark the moan she makes. Now the dog all this while sheds not a tear nor speaks a word; but see how I lay the dust with my tears.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: Lance, away, away! Aboard! Thy master is shipped, and thou art to post after with oars. What's the matter? Why weep'st thou, man? Away, ass. You'll lose the tide if you tarry any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: It is no matter if the tied were lost, for it is the unkindest tied that ever any man tied.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: What's the unkindest tide?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Why, he that's tied here, Crab, my dog.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: Tut, man, I mean thou'lt lose the flood, and, in losing the flood, lose thy voyage, and, in losing thy voyage, lose thy master, and, in losing thy master, lose thy service, and, in losing thy service-why dost thou stop my mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: For fear thou shouldst lose thy tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: Where should I lose my tongue?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: In thy tale.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: In thy tail!

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Lose the tide, and the voyage, and the master, and the service, and the tied? Why, man, if the river were dry, I am able to fill it with my tears; if the wind were down, I could drive the boat with my sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: Come, come away, man. I was sent to call thee.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Sir, call me what thou dar'st.

dialogues.speaker: Pantino
dialogues.line: Will thou go?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Well, I will go.

scenes.location: Milan. A room in the Duke's palace

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Servant!

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Mistress?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Master, Sir Thurio frowns on you.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Ay, boy, it's for love.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Not of you.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Of my mistress, then.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: 'Twere good you knocked him.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Servant, you are sad.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Indeed, madam, I seem so.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Seem you that you are not?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Haply I do.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: So do counterfeits.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: So do you.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: What seem I that I am not?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Wise.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: What instance of the contrary?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Your folly.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: And how quote you my folly?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I quote it in your jerkin.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: My jerkin is a doublet.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Well, then, I'll double your folly.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: How!

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: What, angry, Sir Thurio? Do you change colour?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Give him leave, madam, he is a kind of chameleon.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: That hath more mind to feed on your blood than live in your air.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: You have said, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, and done too, for this time.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I know it well, sir. You always end ere you begin.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: A fine volley of words, gentlemen, and quickly shot off.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: 'Tis indeed, madam, we thank the giver.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Who is that, servant?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Yourself, sweet lady, for you gave the fire. Sir Thurio borrows his wit from your ladyship's looks, and spends what he borrows kindly in your company.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Sir, if you spend word for word with me, I shall make your wit bankrupt.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I know it well, sir. You have an exchequer of words and, I think, no other treasure to give your followers, for it appears by their bare liveries that they live by your bare words.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: No more, gentlemen, no more. Here comes my father.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Now, daughter Silvia, you are hard beset. Sir Valentine, your father is in good health. What say you to a letter from your friends Of much good news?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: My lord, I will be thankful To any happy messenger from thence.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Know ye Don Antonio, your countryman?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord, I know the gentleman To be of worth and worthy estimation, And not without desert so well reputed.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Hath he not a son?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord, a son that well deserves The honour and regard of such a father.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You know him well?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I knew him as myself, for from our infancy We have conversed and spent our hours together. And though myself have been an idle truant, Omitting the sweet benefit of time To clothe mine age with angel-like perfection, Yet hath Sir Proteus, for that's his name, Made use and fair advantage of his days: His years but young, but his experience old; His head unmellowed, but his judgement ripe; And in a word, for far behind his worth Comes all the praises that I now bestow, He is complete in feature and in mind, With all good grace to grace a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Beshrew me, sir, but if he make this good, He is as worthy for an empress' love As meet to be an emperor's counsellor. Well, sir, this gentleman is come to me With commendation from great potentates, And here he means to spend his time awhile. I think 'tis no unwelcome news to you.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Should I have wished a thing, it had been he.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Welcome him then according to his worth. Silvia, I speak to you, and you, Sir Thurio. For Valentine, I need not cite him to it. I will send him hither to you presently.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: This is the gentleman I told your ladyship Had come along with me but that his mistresss Did hold his eyes locked in her crystal looks.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Belike that now she hath enfranchised them Upon some other pawn for fealty.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Nay, sure, I think she holds them prisoners still.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Nay, then, he should be blind, and being blind How could he see his way to seek out you?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Why, lady, Love hath twenty pair of eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: They say that Love hath not an eye at all.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: To see such lovers, Thurio, as yourself. Upon a homely object, Love can wink.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Have done, have done. Here comes the gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Welcome, dear Proteus! Mistress, I beseech you Confirm his welcome with some special favour.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: His worth is warrant for his welcome hither, If this be he you oft have wished to hear from.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Mistress, it is. Sweet lady, entertain him To be my fellow-servant to your ladyship.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Too low a mistress for so high a servant.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Not so, sweet lady, but too mean a servant To have a look of such a worthy mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Leave off discourse of disability. Sweet lady, entertain him for your servant.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: My duty will I boast of, nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: And duty never yet did want his meed. Servant, you are welcome to a worthless mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: I'll die on him that says so but yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: That you are welcome?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: That you are worthless.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Madam, my lord your father would speak with you.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: I wait upon his pleasure. Come, Sir Thurio, Go with me.-Once more, new servant, welcome. I'll leave you to confer of home affairs; When you have done, we look to hear from you.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: We'll both attend upon your ladyship.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Now, tell me, how do all from whence you came?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Your friends are well and have them much commended.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: And how do yours?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: I left them all in health.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: How does your lady? And how thrives your love?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: My tales of love were wont to weary you; I know you joy not in a love-discourse.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Ay, Proteus, but that life is altered now. I have done penance for contemning Love, Whose high imperious thoughts have punished me With bitter fasts, with penitential groans, With nightly tears, and daily heart-sore sighs; For in revenge of my contempt of love, Love hath chased sleep from my enthralled eyes And made them watchers of mine own heart's sorrow. O gentle Proteus, Love's a mighty lord, And hath so humbled me as I confess There is no woe to his correction, Nor to his service no such joy on earth. Now, no discourse, except it be of love; Now can I break my fast, dine, sup, and sleep Upon the very naked name of love.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Enough; I read your fortune in your eye. Was this the idol that you worship so?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Even she; and is she not a heavenly saint?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: No, but she is an earthly paragon.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Call her divine.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: I will not flatter her.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: O, flatter me, for love delights in praises.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: When I was sick, you gave me bitter pills, And I must minister the like to you.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Then speak the truth by her; if not divine, Yet let her be a principality, Sovereign to all the creatures on the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Except my mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Sweet, except not any, Except thou wilt except against my love.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Have I not reason to prefer mine own?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: And I will help thee to prefer her too: She shall be dignified with this high honour, To bear my lady's train, lest the base earth Should from her vesture chance to steal a kiss, And, of so great a favour growing proud, Disdain to root the summer-swelling flower And make rough winter everlastingly.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Why, Valentine, what braggartism is this?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Pardon me, Proteus, all I can is nothing To her, whose worth makes other worthies nothing; She is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Then let her alone.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Not for the world! Why, man, she is mine own, And I as rich in having such a jewel As twenty seas, if all their sand were pearl, The water nectar, and the rocks pure gold. Forgive me that I do not dream on thee, Because thou seest me dote upon my love. My foolish rival, that her father likes Only for his possessions are so huge, Is gone with her along, and I must after, For love, thou know'st, is full of jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: But she loves you?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Ay, and we are betrothed; nay more, our marriage hour, With all the cunning manner of our flight, Determined of: how I must climb her window, The ladder made of cords, and all the means Plotted and 'greed on for my happiness. Good Proteus, go with me to my chamber, In these affairs to aid me with thy counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Go on before; I shall enquire you forth. I must unto the road to disembark Some necessaries that I needs must use, And then I'll presently attend you.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Will you make haste?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: I will. Even as one heat another heat expels, Or as one nail by strength drives out another, So the remembrance of my former love Is by a newer object quite forgotten. Is it mine eye, or Valentine's praise, Her true perfection, or my false transgression, That makes me reasonless to reason thus? She is fair; and so is Julia that I love- That I did love, for now my love is thawed, Which like a waxen image 'gainst a fire Bears no impression of the thing it was. Methinks my zeal to Valentine is cold, And that I love him not as I was wont. O, but I love his lady too too much, And that's the reason I love him so little. How shall I dote on her with more advice That thus without advice begin to love her? 'Tis but her picture I have yet beheld, And that hath dazzled my reason's light; But when I look on her perfections, There is no reason but I shall be blind. If I can check my erring love, I will; If not, to compass her I'll use my skill.

scenes.location: The same. A street

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Lance, by mine honesty, welcome to Milan!

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Forswear not thyself, sweet youth, for I am not welcome. I reckon this always, that a man is never undone till he be hanged, nor never welcome to a place till some certain shot be paid and the hostess say "Welcome".

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Come on, you madcap. I'll to the alehouse with you presently, where, for one shot of five pence, thou shalt have five thousand welcomes. But, sirrah, how did thy master part with Madam Julia?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Marry, after they closed in earnest, they parted very fairly in jest.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: But shall she marry him?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: How then? Shall he marry her?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: No, neither.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: What, are they broken?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: No, they are both as whole as a fish.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Why then, how stands the matter with them?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Marry, thus: when it stands well with him, it stands well with her.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: What an ass art thou! I understand thee not.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: What a block art thou that thou canst not! My staff understands me.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: What thou sayst?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Ay, and what I do too. Look thee, I'll but lean, and my staff understands me.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: It stands under thee indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Why, stand-under and under-stand is all one.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: But tell me true, will't be a match?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Ask my dog. If he say "Ay", it will; if he say "No", it will; if he shake his tail and say nothing, it will.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: The conclusion is, then, that it will.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Thou shalt never get such a secret from me but by a parable.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: 'Tis well that I get it so. But, Lance, how sayst thou that my master is become a notable lover?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: I never knew him otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Than how?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: A notable lubber, as thou reportest him to be.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Why, thou whoreson ass, thou mistak'st me.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Why, fool, I meant not thee, I meant thy master.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: I tell thee, my master is become a hot lover.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Why, I tell thee, I care not though he burn himself in love. If thou wilt, go with me to the alehouse; if not, thou art an Hebrew, a Jew, and not worth the name of a Christian.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Because thou hast not so much charity in thee as to go to the ale with a Christian. Wilt thou go?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: At thy service.

scenes.location: The same. The Duke's palace

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: To leave my Julia, shall I be forsworn; To love fair Silvia, shall I be forsworn; To wrong my friend, I shall be much forsworn. And e'en that power which gave me first my oath Provokes me to this threefold perjury. Love bade me swear, and Love bids me forswear. O sweet-suggesting Love, if thou hast sinned, Teach me, thy tempted subject, to excuse it. At first I did adore a twinkling star, But now I worship a celestial sun. Unheedful vows may heedfully be broken, And he wants wit that wants resolved will To learn his wit t' exchange the bad for better. Fie, fie, unreverend tongue, to call her bad Whose sovereignty so oft thou hast preferred With twenty thousand soul-confirming oaths. I cannot leave to love, and yet I do; But there I leave to love where I should love. Julia I lose, and Valentine I lose; If I keep them, I needs must lose myself; If I lose them, thus find I by their loss, For Valentine, myself; for Julia, Silvia. I to myself am dearer than a friend, For love is still most precious in itself, And Silvia-witness heaven that made her fair- Shows Julia but a swarthy Ethiope. I will forget that Julia is alive, Remembering that my love to her is dead; And Valentine I'll hold an enemy, Aiming at Silvia as a sweeter friend. I cannot now prove constant to myself Without some treachery used to Valentine. This night he meaneth with a corded ladder To climb celestial Silvia's chamber window, Myself in counsel, his competitor. Now presently I'll give her father notice Of their disguising and pretended flight, Who, all enraged, will banish Valentine, For Thurio he intends shall wed his daughter. But Valentine being gone, I'll quickly cross By some sly trick blunt Thurio's dull proceeding. Love, lend me wings to make my purpose swift, As thou hast lent me wit to plot this drift.

scenes.location: Verona. A room in Julia's house

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Counsel, Lucetta; gentle girl, assist me, And ev'n in kind love I do conjure thee, Who art the table wherein all my thoughts Are visibly charactered and engraved, To lesson me and tell me some good mean How with my honour I may undertake A journey to my loving Proteus.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Alas, the way is wearisome and long.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: A true-devoted pilgrim is not weary To measure kingdoms with his feeble steps; Much less shall she that hath Love's wings to fly, And when the flight is made to one so dear, Of such divine perfection, as Sir Proteus.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Better forbear till Proteus make return.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: O, know'st thou not his looks are my soul's food? Pity the dearth that I have pined in By longing for that food so long a time. Didst thou but know the inly touch of love Thou wouldst as soon go kindle fire with snow As seek to quench the fire of love with words.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: I do not seek to quench your love's hot fire, But qualify the fire's extreme rage, Lest it should burn above the bounds of reason.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: The more thou damm'st it up, the more it burns. The current that with gentle murmur glides, Thou know'st, being stopped, impatiently doth rage; But when his fair course is not hindered, He makes sweet music with th' enamelled stones, Giving a gentle kiss to every sedge He overtaketh in his pilgrimage; And so by many winding nooks he strays With willing sport to the wild ocean. Then let me go and hinder not my course. I'll be as patient as a gentle stream And make a pastime of each weary step Till the last step have brought me to my love, And there I'll rest as after much turmoil A blessed soul doth in Elysium.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: But in what habit will you go along?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Not like a woman, for I would prevent The loose encounters of lascivious men. Gentle Lucetta, fit me with such weeds As may beseem some well-reputed page.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Why then, your ladyship must cut your hair.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: No, girl, I'll knit it up in silken strings With twenty odd-conceited true-love knots. To be fantastic may become a youth Of greater time than I shall show to be.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: What fashion, madam, shall I make your breeches?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: That fits as well as "Tell me, good my lord, What compass will you wear your farthingale?" Why e'en what fashion thou best likes, Lucetta.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: You must needs have them with a codpiece, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Out, out, Lucetta, that will be ill-favoured.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: A round hose, madam, now's not worth a pin Unless you have a codpiece to stick pins on.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Lucetta, as thou lov'st me, let me have What thou think'st meet and is most mannerly. But tell me, wench, how will the world repute me For undertaking so unstaid a journey? I fear me it will make me scandalized.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: If you think so, then stay at home and go not.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Nay, that I will not.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Then never dream on infamy, but go. If Proteus like your journey when you come, No matter who's displeased when you are gone. I fear me he will scarce be pleased withal.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: That is the least, Lucetta, of my fear. A thousand oaths, an ocean of his tears, And instances of infinite of love, Warrant me welcome to my Proteus.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: All these are servants to deceitful men.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Base men that use them to so base effect! But truer stars did govern Proteus' birth. His words are bonds, his oaths are oracles, His love sincere, his thoughts immaculate, His tears pure messengers sent from his heart, His heart as far from fraud as heaven from earth.

dialogues.speaker: Lucetta
dialogues.line: Pray heav'n he prove so when you come to him.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Now, as thou lov'st me, do him not that wrong To bear a hard opinion of his truth. Only deserve my love by loving him. And presently go with me to my chamber To take a note of what I stand in need of To furnish me upon my longing journey. All that is mine I leave at thy dispose, My goods, my lands, my reputation; Only, in lieu thereof, dispatch me hence. Come, answer not, but to it presently. I am impatient of my tarriance.

scenes.location: Milan. An anteroom in the Duke's palace

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Sir Thurio, give us leave, I pray, awhile; We have some secrets to confer about. Now tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: My gracious lord, that which I would discover The law of friendship bids me to conceal, But when I call to mind your gracious favours Done to me, undeserving as I am, My duty pricks me on to utter that Which else no worldly good should draw from me. Know, worthy prince, Sir Valentine my friend This night intends to steal away your daughter; Myself am one made privy to the plot. I know you have determined to bestow her On Thurio, whom your gentle daughter hates, And should she thus be stol'n away from you, It would be much vexation to your age. Thus, for my duty's sake, I rather chose To cross my friend in his intended drift Than, by concealing it, heap on your head A pack of sorrows which would press you down, Being unprevented, to your timeless grave.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Proteus, I thank thee for thine honest care, Which to requite command me while I live. This love of theirs myself have often seen, Haply when they have judged me fast asleep, And oftentimes have purposed to forbid Sir Valentine her company and my court. But fearing lest my jealous aim might err And so, unworthily, disgrace the man- A rashness that I ever yet have shunned- I gave him gentle looks, thereby to find That which thyself hast now disclosed to me. And that thou mayst perceive my fear of this, Knowing that tender youth is soon suggested, I nightly lodge her in an upper tower, The key whereof myself have ever kept; And thence she cannot be conveyed away.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Know, noble lord, they have devised a mean How he her chamber-window will ascend And with a corded ladder fetch her down; For which the youthful lover now is gone, And this way comes he with it presently, Where, if it please you, you may intercept him. But, good my lord, do it so cunningly That my discovery be not aimed at; For love of you, not hate unto my friend, Hath made me publisher of this pretence.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Upon mine honour, he shall never know That I had any light from thee of this.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Adieu, my lord, Sir Valentine is coming.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Sir Valentine, whither away so fast?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Please it your Grace, there is a messenger That stays to bear my letters to my friends, And I am going to deliver them.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Be they of much import?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: The tenor of them doth but signify My health and happy being at your court.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Nay then, no matter. Stay with me awhile; I am to break with thee of some affairs That touch me near, wherein thou must be secret. 'Tis not unknown to thee that I have sought To match my friend Sir Thurio to my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I know it well, my lord, and sure the match Were rich and honourable. Besides, the gentleman Is full of virtue, bounty, worth, and qualities Beseeming such a wife as your fair daughter. Cannot your grace win her to fancy him?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: No, trust me, she is peevish, sullen, froward, Proud, disobedient, stubborn, lacking duty, Neither regarding that she is my child Nor fearing me as if I were her father; And, may I say to thee, this pride of hers, Upon advice, hath drawn my love from her, And where I thought the remnant of mine age Should have been cherished by her childlike duty, I now am full resolved to take a wife And turn her out to who will take her in. Then let her beauty be her wedding dower, For me and my possessions she esteems not.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: What would your Grace have me to do in this?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: There is a lady of Verona here Whom I affect; but she is nice, and coy, And nought esteems my aged eloquence. Now therefore would I have thee to my tutor- For long agone I have forgot to court; Besides, the fashion of the time is changed- How and which way I may bestow myself To be regarded in her sun-bright eye.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Win her with gifts if she respect not words; Dumb jewels often in their silent kind More than quick words do move a woman's mind.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: But she did scorn a present that I sent her.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: A woman sometime scorns what best contents her. Send her another; never give her o'er, For scorn at first makes after-love the more. If she do frown, 'tis not in hate of you, But rather to beget more love in you. If she do chide, 'tis not to have you gone, Forwhy the fools are mad if left alone. Take no repulse, whatever she doth say; For "Get you gone" she doth not mean "Away!" Flatter and praise, commend, extol their graces; Though ne'er so black, say they have angels' faces. That man that hath a tongue, I say, is no man If with his tongue he cannot win a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: But she I mean is promised by her friends Unto a youthful gentleman of worth, And kept severely from resort of men, That no man hath access by day to her.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Why then, I would resort to her by night.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Ay, but the doors be locked and keys kept safe, That no man hath recourse to her by night.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: What lets but one may enter at her window?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Her chamber is aloft, far from the ground, And built so shelving that one cannot climb it Without apparent hazard of his life.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Why, then a ladder quaintly made of cords To cast up with a pair of anchoring hooks, Would serve to scale another Hero's tower, So bold Leander would adventure it.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Now, as thou art a gentleman of blood, Advise me where I may have such a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: When would you use it? Pray, sir, tell me that.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: This very night; for Love is like a child That longs for everything that he can come by.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: By seven o'clock I'll get you such a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: But, hark thee: I will go to her alone; How shall I best convey the ladder thither?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: It will be light, my lord, that you may bear it Under a cloak that is of any length.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: A cloak as long as thine will serve the turn?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Ay, my good lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Then let me see thy cloak; I'll get me one of such another length.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Why, any cloak will serve the turn, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: How shall I fashion me to wear a cloak? I pray thee, let me feel thy cloak upon me.  What letter is this same? What's here?-_To Silvia?_ And here an engine fit for my proceeding. I'll be so bold to break the seal for once.  _My thoughts do harbour with my Silvia nightly, And slaves they are to me that send them flying. O, could their master come and go as lightly, Himself would lodge where, senseless, they are lying. My herald thoughts in thy pure bosom rest them, While I, their king, that thither them importune, Do curse the grace that with such grace hath blest them, Because myself do want my servants' fortune. I curse myself, for they are sent by me, That they should harbour where their lord should be._ What's here?  _Silvia, this night I will enfranchise thee._ 'Tis so; and here's the ladder for the purpose. Why, Phathon-for thou art Merops' son- Wilt thou aspire to guide the heavenly car, And with thy daring folly burn the world? Wilt thou reach stars because they shine on thee? Go, base intruder, overweening slave, Bestow thy fawning smiles on equal mates, And think my patience, more than thy desert, Is privilege for thy departure hence. Thank me for this more than for all the favours Which, all too much, I have bestowed on thee. But if thou linger in my territories Longer than swiftest expedition Will give thee time to leave our royal court, By heaven, my wrath shall far exceed the love I ever bore my daughter or thyself. Begone, I will not hear thy vain excuse, But, as thou lov'st thy life, make speed from hence.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: And why not death, rather than living torment? To die is to be banished from myself, And Silvia is myself; banished from her Is self from self-a deadly banishment. What light is light, if Silvia be not seen? What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by? Unless it be to think that she is by And feed upon the shadow of perfection. Except I be by Silvia in the night, There is no music in the nightingale. Unless I look on Silvia in the day, There is no day for me to look upon. She is my essence, and I leave to be If I be not by her fair influence Fostered, illumined, cherished, kept alive. I fly not death, to fly his deadly doom: Tarry I here, I but attend on death, But fly I hence, I fly away from life.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Run, boy, run, run, seek him out.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: So-ho, so-ho!

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: What seest thou?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Him we go to find. There's not a hair on 's head but 'tis a Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Valentine?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Who then? His spirit?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Neither.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: What then?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Can nothing speak? Master, shall I strike?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Who wouldst thou strike?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Villain, forbear.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Why, sir, I'll strike nothing. I pray you-

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Sirrah, I say, forbear.-Friend Valentine, a word.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: My ears are stopped and cannot hear good news, So much of bad already hath possessed them.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Then in dumb silence will I bury mine, For they are harsh, untuneable, and bad.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Is Silvia dead?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: No, Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: No Valentine indeed for sacred Silvia. Hath she forsworn me?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: No, Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: No Valentine, if Silvia have forsworn me. What is your news?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Sir, there is a proclamation that you are vanished.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: That thou art banished-O, that's the news- From hence, from Silvia, and from me thy friend.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: O, I have fed upon this woe already, And now excess of it will make me surfeit. Doth Silvia know that I am banished?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Ay, ay; and she hath offered to the doom- Which unreversed stands in effectual force- A sea of melting pearl, which some call tears; Those at her father's churlish feet she tendered, With them, upon her knees, her humble self, Wringing her hands, whose whiteness so became them As if but now they waxed pale for woe. But neither bended knees, pure hands held up, Sad sighs, deep groans, nor silver-shedding tears Could penetrate her uncompassionate sire; But Valentine, if he be ta'en, must die. Besides, her intercession chafed him so, When she for thy repeal was suppliant, That to close prison he commanded her, With many bitter threats of biding there.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: No more, unless the next word that thou speak'st Have some malignant power upon my life. If so, I pray thee breathe it in mine ear, As ending anthem of my endless dolour.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Cease to lament for that thou canst not help, And study help for that which thou lament'st. Time is the nurse and breeder of all good. Here if thou stay, thou canst not see thy love; Besides, thy staying will abridge thy life. Hope is a lover's staff; walk hence with that And manage it against despairing thoughts. Thy letters may be here, though thou art hence, Which, being writ to me, shall be delivered Even in the milk-white bosom of thy love. The time now serves not to expostulate. Come, I'll convey thee through the city-gate, And, ere I part with thee, confer at large Of all that may concern thy love affairs. As thou lov'st Silvia, though not for thyself, Regard thy danger, and along with me.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I pray thee, Lance, an if thou seest my boy, Bid him make haste and meet me at the North Gate.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Go, sirrah, find him out. Come, Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: O, my dear Silvia! Hapless Valentine!

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: I am but a fool, look you, and yet I have the wit to think my master is a kind of a knave; but that's all one if he be but one knave. He lives not now that knows me to be in love, yet I am in love, but a team of horse shall not pluck that from me, nor who 'tis I love; and yet 'tis a woman, but what woman I will not tell myself; and yet 'tis a milkmaid; yet 'tis not a maid, for she hath had gossips; yet 'tis a maid, for she is her master's maid and serves for wages. She hath more qualities than a water-spaniel, which is much in a bare Christian.  Here is the cate-log of her condition. _Imprimis, She can fetch and carry_. Why, a horse can do no more; nay, a horse cannot fetch but only carry; therefore is she better than a jade. _Item, She can milk_. Look you, a sweet virtue in a maid with clean hands.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: How now, Signior Lance? What news with your mastership?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: With my master's ship? Why, it is at sea.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Well, your old vice still: mistake the word. What news, then, in your paper?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: The blackest news that ever thou heard'st.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Why, man? How black?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Why, as black as ink.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Let me read them.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Fie on thee, jolt-head, thou canst not read.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Thou liest. I can.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: I will try thee. Tell me this, who begot thee?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Marry, the son of my grandfather.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: O, illiterate loiterer! It was the son of thy grandmother. This proves that thou canst not read.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Come, fool, come; try me in thy paper.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: There; and Saint Nicholas be thy speed.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Imprimis, She can milk._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Ay, that she can.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She brews good ale._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: And thereof comes the proverb, "Blessing of your heart, you brew good ale."

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She can sew._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: That's as much as to say, "Can she so?"

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She can knit._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: What need a man care for a stock with a wench, when she can knit him a stock?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She can wash and scour._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: A special virtue, for then she need not be washed and scoured.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She can spin._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Then may I set the world on wheels, when she can spin for her living.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She hath many nameless virtues._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: That's as much as to say, "bastard virtues", that indeed know not their fathers, and therefore have no names.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Here follow her vices.

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Close at the heels of her virtues.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She is not to be kissed fasting in respect of her breath._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Well, that fault may be mended with a breakfast. Read on.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She hath a sweet mouth._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: That makes amends for her sour breath.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She doth talk in her sleep._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: It's no matter for that, so she sleep not in her talk.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She is slow in words._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: O villain, that set this down among her vices! To be slow in words is a woman's only virtue. I pray thee, out with't, and place it for her chief virtue.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She is proud._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Out with that too; it was Eve's legacy and cannot be ta'en from her.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She hath no teeth._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: I care not for that neither, because I love crusts.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She is curst._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Well, the best is, she hath no teeth to bite.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She will often praise her liquor._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: If her liquor be good, she shall; if she will not, I will, for good things should be praised.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She is too liberal._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Of her tongue she cannot, for that's writ down she is slow of; of her purse she shall not, for that I'll keep shut. Now, of another thing she may, and that cannot I help. Well, proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She hath more hair than wit, and more faults than hairs, and more wealth than faults._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Stop there; I'll have her. She was mine and not mine twice or thrice in that last article. Rehearse that once more.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _Item, She hath more hair than wit_-

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: More hair than wit. It may be; I'll prove it: the cover of the salt hides the salt, and therefore it is more than the salt; the hair that covers the wit is more than the wit, for the greater hides the less. What's next?

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _And more faults than hairs._

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: That's monstrous! O, that that were out!

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: _And more wealth than faults._
