dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Why, that word makes the faults gracious. Well, I'll have her; an if it be a match, as nothing is impossible-

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: What then?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Why, then will I tell thee that thy master stays for thee at the North Gate.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: For me?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: For thee? Ay, who art thou? He hath stayed for a better man than thee.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: And must I go to him?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Thou must run to him, for thou hast stayed so long that going will scarce serve the turn.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Why didst not tell me sooner? Pox of your love letters!

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Now will he be swinged for reading my letter; an unmannerly slave, that will thrust himself into secrets. I'll after, to rejoice in the boy's correction.

scenes.location: The same. A room in the Duke's palace

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Sir Thurio, fear not but that she will love you Now Valentine is banished from her sight.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Since his exile she hath despised me most, Forsworn my company and railed at me, That I am desperate of obtaining her.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: This weak impress of love is as a figure Trenched in ice, which with an hour's heat Dissolves to water and doth lose his form. A little time will melt her frozen thoughts, And worthless Valentine shall be forgot. How now, Sir Proteus? Is your countryman, According to our proclamation, gone?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Gone, my good lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: My daughter takes his going grievously.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: A little time, my lord, will kill that grief.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: So I believe, but Thurio thinks not so. Proteus, the good conceit I hold of thee, For thou hast shown some sign of good desert, Makes me the better to confer with thee.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Longer than I prove loyal to your Grace Let me not live to look upon your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Thou know'st how willingly I would effect The match between Sir Thurio and my daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: I do, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: And also, I think, thou art not ignorant How she opposes her against my will?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: She did, my lord, when Valentine was here.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Ay, and perversely she persevers so. What might we do to make the girl forget The love of Valentine, and love Sir Thurio?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: The best way is to slander Valentine With falsehood, cowardice, and poor descent, Three things that women highly hold in hate.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Ay, but she'll think that it is spoke in hate.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Ay, if his enemy deliver it; Therefore it must with circumstance be spoken By one whom she esteemeth as his friend.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Then you must undertake to slander him.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: And that, my lord, I shall be loath to do. 'Tis an ill office for a gentleman, Especially against his very friend.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Where your good word cannot advantage him, Your slander never can endamage him; Therefore the office is indifferent, Being entreated to it by your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: You have prevailed, my lord. If I can do it By aught that I can speak in his dispraise, She shall not long continue love to him. But say this weed her love from Valentine, It follows not that she will love Sir Thurio.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Therefore, as you unwind her love from him, Lest it should ravel and be good to none, You must provide to bottom it on me, Which must be done by praising me as much As you in worth dispraise Sir Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: And, Proteus, we dare trust you in this kind Because we know, on Valentine's report, You are already Love's firm votary And cannot soon revolt and change your mind. Upon this warrant shall you have access Where you with Silvia may confer at large- For she is lumpish, heavy, melancholy, And, for your friend's sake, will be glad of you- Where you may temper her by your persuasion To hate young Valentine and love my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: As much as I can do I will effect. But you, Sir Thurio, are not sharp enough. You must lay lime to tangle her desires By wailful sonnets, whose composed rhymes Should be full-fraught with serviceable vows.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Ay, much is the force of heaven-bred poesy.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Say that upon the altar of her beauty You sacrifice your tears, your sighs, your heart. Write till your ink be dry, and with your tears Moist it again, and frame some feeling line That may discover such integrity. For Orpheus' lute was strung with poets' sinews, Whose golden touch could soften steel and stones, Make tigers tame, and huge leviathans Forsake unsounded deeps to dance on sands. After your dire-lamenting elegies, Visit by night your lady's chamber-window With some sweet consort; to their instruments Tune a deploring dump; the night's dead silence Will well become such sweet-complaining grievance. This, or else nothing, will inherit her.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: This discipline shows thou hast been in love.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: And thy advice this night I'll put in practice. Therefore, sweet Proteus, my direction-giver, Let us into the city presently To sort some gentlemen well skilled in music. I have a sonnet that will serve the turn To give the onset to thy good advice.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: About it, gentlemen!

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: We'll wait upon your Grace till after supper, And afterward determine our proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Even now about it! I will pardon you.

scenes.location: A forest between Milan and Verona

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: Fellows, stand fast. I see a passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: If there be ten, shrink not, but down with 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Third Outlaw
dialogues.line: Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about ye. If not, we'll make you sit, and rifle you.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Sir, we are undone: these are the villains That all the travellers do fear so much.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: My friends-

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: That's not so, sir. We are your enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: Peace! We'll hear him.

dialogues.speaker: Third Outlaw
dialogues.line: Ay, by my beard, will we, for he is a proper man.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Then know that I have little wealth to lose. A man I am crossed with adversity; My riches are these poor habiliments, Of which if you should here disfurnish me, You take the sum and substance that I have.

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: Whither travel you?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: To Verona.

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: Whence came you?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: From Milan.

dialogues.speaker: Third Outlaw
dialogues.line: Have you long sojourned there?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Some sixteen months, and longer might have stayed If crooked fortune had not thwarted me.

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: What, were you banished thence?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I was.

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: For what offence?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: For that which now torments me to rehearse; I killed a man, whose death I much repent, But yet I slew him manfully in fight, Without false vantage or base treachery.

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: Why, ne'er repent it, if it were done so. But were you banished for so small a fault?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I was, and held me glad of such a doom.

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: Have you the tongues?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: My youthful travel therein made me happy, Or else I often had been miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Third Outlaw
dialogues.line: By the bare scalp of Robin Hood's fat friar, This fellow were a king for our wild faction.

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: We'll have him. Sirs, a word.

dialogues.speaker: Speed
dialogues.line: Master, be one of them. It's an honourable kind of thievery.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Peace, villain.

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: Tell us this: have you anything to take to?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Nothing but my fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Third Outlaw
dialogues.line: Know then that some of us are gentlemen, Such as the fury of ungoverned youth Thrust from the company of awful men. Myself was from Verona banished For practising to steal away a lady, An heir, and near allied unto the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: And I from Mantua, for a gentleman Who, in my mood, I stabbed unto the heart.

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: And I for suchlike petty crimes as these. But to the purpose, for we cite our faults, That they may hold excused our lawless lives; And partly, seeing you are beautified With goodly shape, and by your own report A linguist, and a man of such perfection As we do in our quality much want-

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: Indeed because you are a banished man, Therefore, above the rest, we parley to you. Are you content to be our general? To make a virtue of necessity And live as we do in this wilderness?

dialogues.speaker: Third Outlaw
dialogues.line: What sayst thou? Wilt thou be of our consort? Say "Ay", and be the captain of us all, We'll do thee homage and be ruled by thee, Love thee as our commander and our king.

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offered.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I take your offer and will live with you, Provided that you do no outrages On silly women or poor passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Third Outlaw
dialogues.line: No, we detest such vile base practices. Come, go with us; we'll bring thee to our crews And show thee all the treasure we have got, Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose.

scenes.location: Milan. The court of the Duke's palace

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Already have I been false to Valentine, And now I must be as unjust to Thurio. Under the colour of commending him, I have access my own love to prefer. But Silvia is too fair, too true, too holy To be corrupted with my worthless gifts. When I protest true loyalty to her, She twits me with my falsehood to my friend; When to her beauty I commend my vows, She bids me think how I have been forsworn In breaking faith with Julia, whom I loved; And notwithstanding all her sudden quips, The least whereof would quell a lover's hope, Yet, spaniel-like, the more she spurns my love, The more it grows and fawneth on her still. But here comes Thurio. Now must we to her window, And give some evening music to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: How now, Sir Proteus, are you crept before us?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Ay, gentle Thurio, for you know that love Will creep in service where it cannot go.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Ay, but I hope, sir, that you love not here.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Sir, but I do, or else I would be hence.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Who? Silvia?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Ay, Silvia, for your sake.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: I thank you for your own. Now, gentlemen, Let's tune, and to it lustily awhile. Enter Host and Julia in boy's clothes, as Sebastian.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Now, my young guest, methinks you're allycholly. I pray you, why is it?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Marry, mine host, because I cannot be merry.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Come, we'll have you merry. I'll bring you where you shall hear music, and see the gentleman that you asked for.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: But shall I hear him speak?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Ay, that you shall.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: That will be music.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Hark, hark!

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Is he among these?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Ay; but peace, let's hear 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Who is Silvia? What is she, That all our swains commend her? Holy, fair, and wise is she; The heaven such grace did lend her, That she might admired be. Is she kind as she is fair? For beauty lives with kindness. Love doth to her eyes repair, To help him of his blindness; And, being helped, inhabits there. Then to Silvia let us sing, That Silvia is excelling; She excels each mortal thing Upon the dull earth dwelling. To her let us garlands bring.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: How now, are you sadder than you were before? How do you, man? The music likes you not.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: You mistake; the musician likes me not.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Why, my pretty youth?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: He plays false, father.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: How, out of tune on the strings?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Not so; but yet so false that he grieves my very heart-strings.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: You have a quick ear.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Ay, I would I were deaf; it makes me have a slow heart.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: I perceive you delight not in music.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Not a whit, when it jars so.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Hark, what fine change is in the music!

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Ay, that change is the spite.

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: You would have them always play but one thing?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: I would always have one play but one thing. But, host, doth this Sir Proteus, that we talk on, Often resort unto this gentlewoman?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: I tell you what Lance, his man, told me: he loved her out of all nick.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Where is Lance?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Gone to seek his dog, which tomorrow, by his master's command, he must carry for a present to his lady.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Peace, stand aside. The company parts.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Sir Thurio, fear not you; I will so plead That you shall say my cunning drift excels.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Where meet we?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: At Saint Gregory's well.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Madam, good even to your ladyship.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: I thank you for your music, gentlemen. Who is that that spake?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: One, lady, if you knew his pure heart's truth, You would quickly learn to know him by his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Sir Proteus, as I take it.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Sir Proteus, gentle lady, and your servant.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: What's your will?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: That I may compass yours.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: You have your wish. My will is even this, That presently you hie you home to bed. Thou subtle, perjured, false, disloyal man, Think'st thou I am so shallow, so conceitless, To be seduced by thy flattery, That hast deceived so many with thy vows? Return, return, and make thy love amends. For me, by this pale queen of night I swear, I am so far from granting thy request That I despise thee for thy wrongful suit, And by and by intend to chide myself Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: I grant, sweet love, that I did love a lady, But she is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: 'Twere false, if I should speak it, For I am sure she is not buried.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Say that she be; yet Valentine thy friend Survives, to whom, thyself art witness, I am betrothed. And art thou not ashamed To wrong him with thy importunacy?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: And so suppose am I, for in his grave, Assure thyself, my love is buried.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Sweet lady, let me rake it from the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Go to thy lady's grave and call hers thence, Or, at the least, in hers sepulchre thine.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: He heard not that.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Madam, if your heart be so obdurate, Vouchsafe me yet your picture for my love, The picture that is hanging in your chamber; To that I'll speak, to that I'll sigh and weep; For since the substance of your perfect self Is else devoted, I am but a shadow; And to your shadow will I make true love.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: If 'twere a substance you would sure deceive it And make it but a shadow, as I am.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: I am very loath to be your idol, sir; But since your falsehood shall become you well To worship shadows and adore false shapes, Send to me in the morning, and I'll send it. And so, good rest.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: As wretches have o'ernight That wait for execution in the morn.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Host, will you go?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: By my halidom, I was fast asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Pray you, where lies Sir Proteus?

dialogues.speaker: Host
dialogues.line: Marry, at my house. Trust me, I think 'tis almost day.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Not so; but it hath been the longest night That e'er I watched, and the most heaviest.

scenes.location: The same

dialogues.speaker: Eglamour
dialogues.line: This is the hour that Madam Silvia Entreated me to call and know her mind; There's some great matter she'd employ me in. Madam, madam!

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Who calls?

dialogues.speaker: Eglamour
dialogues.line: Your servant and your friend; One that attends your ladyship's command.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morrow.

dialogues.speaker: Eglamour
dialogues.line: As many, worthy lady, to yourself. According to your ladyship's impose, I am thus early come to know what service It is your pleasure to command me in.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: O Eglamour, thou art a gentleman- Think not I flatter, for I swear I do not- Valiant, wise, remorseful, well accomplished. Thou art not ignorant what dear good will I bear unto the banished Valentine, Nor how my father would enforce me marry Vain Thurio, whom my very soul abhorred. Thyself hast loved, and I have heard thee say No grief did ever come so near thy heart As when thy lady and thy true love died, Upon whose grave thou vowed'st pure chastity. Sir Eglamour, I would to Valentine, To Mantua, where I hear he makes abode; And for the ways are dangerous to pass, I do desire thy worthy company, Upon whose faith and honour I repose. Urge not my father's anger, Eglamour, But think upon my grief, a lady's grief, And on the justice of my flying hence To keep me from a most unholy match, Which heaven and fortune still rewards with plagues. I do desire thee, even from a heart As full of sorrows as the sea of sands, To bear me company and go with me; If not, to hide what I have said to thee, That I may venture to depart alone.

dialogues.speaker: Eglamour
dialogues.line: Madam, I pity much your grievances, Which, since I know they virtuously are placed, I give consent to go along with you, Recking as little what betideth me As much I wish all good befortune you. When will you go?

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: This evening coming.

dialogues.speaker: Eglamour
dialogues.line: Where shall I meet you?

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: At Friar Patrick's cell, Where I intend holy confession.

dialogues.speaker: Eglamour
dialogues.line: I will not fail your ladyship. Good morrow, gentle lady.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamour.

scenes.location: The same

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: When a man's servant shall play the cur with him, look you, it goes hard: one that I brought up of a puppy; one that I saved from drowning when three or four of his blind brothers and sisters went to it. I have taught him even as one would say precisely, "Thus I would teach a dog." I was sent to deliver him as a present to Mistress Silvia from my master; and I came no sooner into the dining-chamber but he steps me to her trencher and steals her capon's leg. O, 'tis a foul thing when a cur cannot keep himself in all companies! I would have, as one should say, one that takes upon him to be a dog indeed, to be, as it were, a dog at all things. If I had not had more wit than he, to take a fault upon me that he did, I think verily he had been hanged for't; sure as I live, he had suffered for't. You shall judge. He thrusts me himself into the company of three or four gentleman-like dogs under the Duke's table; he had not been there-bless the mark!-a pissing-while but all the chamber smelt him. "Out with the dog!" says one; "What cur is that?" says another; "Whip him out", says the third; "Hang him up", says the Duke. I, having been acquainted with the smell before, knew it was Crab, and goes me to the fellow that whips the dogs. "Friend," quoth I, "you mean to whip the dog?" "Ay, marry do I," quoth he. "You do him the more wrong," quoth I. "'Twas I did the thing you wot of." He makes me no more ado but whips me out of the chamber. How many masters would do this for his servant? Nay, I'll be sworn I have sat in the stock for puddings he hath stolen, otherwise he had been executed. I have stood on the pillory for geese he hath killed, otherwise he had suffered for't.  Thou think'st not of this now. Nay, I remember the trick you served me when I took my leave of Madam Silvia. Did not I bid thee still mark me, and do as I do? When didst thou see me heave up my leg and make water against a gentlewoman's farthingale? Didst thou ever see me do such a trick?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Sebastian is thy name? I like thee well, And will employ thee in some service presently.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: In what you please; I'll do what I can.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: I hope thou wilt.  How now, you whoreson peasant, Where have you been these two days loitering?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade me.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: And what says she to my little jewel?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Marry, she says your dog was a cur, and tells you currish thanks is good enough for such a present.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: But she received my dog?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: No, indeed, did she not. Here have I brought him back again.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: What, didst thou offer her this from me?

dialogues.speaker: Lance
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, the other squirrel was stolen from me by the hangman's boys in the market-place, and then I offered her mine own, who is a dog as big as ten of yours, and therefore the gift the greater.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Go, get thee hence, and find my dog again, Or ne'er return again into my sight. Away, I say. Stayest thou to vex me here? A slave that still an end turns me to shame. Sebastian, I have entertained thee Partly that I have need of such a youth That can with some discretion do my business- For 'tis no trusting to yond foolish lout- But chiefly for thy face and thy behaviour, Which, if my augury deceive me not, Witness good bringing up, fortune, and truth. Therefore, know thou, for this I entertain thee. Go presently, and take this ring with thee, Deliver it to Madam Silvia. She loved me well delivered it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: It seems you loved not her, to leave her token. She's dead belike?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Not so; I think she lives.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Alas!

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Why dost thou cry "Alas"?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: I cannot choose But pity her.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Wherefore shouldst thou pity her?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Because methinks that she loved you as well As you do love your lady Silvia. She dreams on him that has forgot her love; You dote on her that cares not for your love. 'Tis pity love should be so contrary; And thinking on it makes me cry "Alas."

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Well, give her that ring, and therewithal This letter. That's her chamber. Tell my lady I claim the promise for her heavenly picture. Your message done, hie home unto my chamber, Where thou shalt find me sad and solitary.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: How many women would do such a message? Alas, poor Proteus, thou hast entertained A fox to be the shepherd of thy lambs. Alas, poor fool, why do I pity him That with his very heart despiseth me? Because he loves her, he despiseth me; Because I love him, I must pity him. This ring I gave him when he parted from me, To bind him to remember my good will; And now am I, unhappy messenger, To plead for that which I would not obtain, To carry that which I would have refused, To praise his faith, which I would have dispraised. I am my master's true confirmed love, But cannot be true servant to my master Unless I prove false traitor to myself. Yet will I woo for him, but yet so coldly As, heaven it knows, I would not have him speed. Gentlewoman, good day. I pray you be my mean To bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: What would you with her, if that I be she?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: If you be she, I do entreat your patience To hear me speak the message I am sent on.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: From whom?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: O, he sends you for a picture?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Ay, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Ursula, bring my picture there. Go, give your master this. Tell him from me, One Julia, that his changing thoughts forget, Would better fit his chamber than this shadow.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Madam, please you peruse this letter. Pardon me, madam, I have unadvised Delivered you a paper that I should not. This is the letter to your ladyship.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: I pray thee, let me look on that again.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: It may not be. Good madam, pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: There, hold. I will not look upon your master's lines. I know they are stuffed with protestations And full of new-found oaths, which he will break As easily as I do tear his paper.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: The more shame for him that he sends it me; For I have heard him say a thousand times His Julia gave it him at his departure. Though his false finger have profaned the ring, Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: She thanks you.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: What sayst thou?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: I thank you, madam, that you tender her. Poor gentlewoman, my master wrongs her much.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Dost thou know her?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Almost as well as I do know myself. To think upon her woes, I do protest That I have wept a hundred several times.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Belike she thinks that Proteus hath forsook her?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: I think she doth, and that's her cause of sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Is she not passing fair?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: She hath been fairer, madam, than she is. When she did think my master loved her well, She, in my judgement, was as fair as you. But since she did neglect her looking-glass And threw her sun-expelling mask away, The air hath starved the roses in her cheeks And pinched the lily-tincture of her face, That now she is become as black as I.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: How tall was she?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: About my stature; for at Pentecost, When all our pageants of delight were played, Our youth got me to play the woman's part, And I was trimmed in Madam Julia's gown, Which served me as fit, by all men's judgements, As if the garment had been made for me; Therefore I know she is about my height. And at that time I made her weep agood, For I did play a lamentable part. Madam, 'twas Ariadne, passioning For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight, Which I so lively acted with my tears That my poor mistress, moved therewithal, Wept bitterly; and would I might be dead If I in thought felt not her very sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: She is beholding to thee, gentle youth. Alas, poor lady, desolate and left! I weep myself to think upon thy words. Here, youth, there is my purse. I give thee this For thy sweet mistress' sake, because thou lov'st her. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: And she shall thank you for't, if e'er you know her. A virtuous gentlewoman, mild and beautiful. I hope my master's suit will be but cold, Since she respects my mistress' love so much. Alas, how love can trifle with itself! Here is her picture; let me see. I think If I had such a tire, this face of mine Were full as lovely as is this of hers; And yet the painter flattered her a little, Unless I flatter with myself too much. Her hair is auburn, mine is perfect yellow; If that be all the difference in his love, I'll get me such a coloured periwig. Her eyes are grey as glass, and so are mine. Ay, but her forehead's low, and mine's as high. What should it be that he respects in her But I can make respective in myself, If this fond Love were not a blinded god? Come, shadow, come, and take this shadow up, For 'tis thy rival. O thou senseless form, Thou shalt be worshipped, kissed, loved, and adored; And were there sense in his idolatry, My substance should be statue in thy stead. I'll use thee kindly for thy mistress' sake, That used me so; or else, by Jove I vow, I should have scratched out your unseeing eyes To make my master out of love with thee.

scenes.location: Milan. An abbey

dialogues.speaker: Eglamour
dialogues.line: The sun begins to gild the western sky, And now it is about the very hour That Silvia at Friar Patrick's cell should meet me. She will not fail, for lovers break not hours, Unless it be to come before their time, So much they spur their expedition. See where she comes. Lady, a happy evening!

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Amen, amen. Go on, good Eglamour, Out at the postern by the abbey wall. I fear I am attended by some spies.

dialogues.speaker: Eglamour
dialogues.line: Fear not. The forest is not three leagues off; If we recover that, we are sure enough.

scenes.location: The same. A room in the Duke's palace

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Sir Proteus, what says Silvia to my suit?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: O, sir, I find her milder than she was, And yet she takes exceptions at your person.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: What? That my leg is too long?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: No, that it is too little.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: I'll wear a boot to make it somewhat rounder.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: But love will not be spurred to what it loathes.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: What says she to my face?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: She says it is a fair one.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Nay, then, the wanton lies; my face is black.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: But pearls are fair; and the old saying is, "Black men are pearls in beauteous ladies' eyes."

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: 'Tis true, such pearls as put out ladies' eyes, For I had rather wink than look on them.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: How likes she my discourse?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Ill, when you talk of war.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: But well when I discourse of love and peace.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: But better, indeed, when you hold your peace.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: What says she to my valour?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: O, sir, she makes no doubt of that.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: What says she to my birth?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: That you are well derived.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: True, from a gentleman to a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Considers she my possessions?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: O, ay, and pities them.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Wherefore?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: That such an ass should owe them.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: That they are out by lease.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Here comes the Duke.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: How now, Sir Proteus! How now, Thurio! Which of you saw Sir Eglamour of late?

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Not I.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Nor I.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Saw you my daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Neither.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Why then, she's fled unto that peasant Valentine, And Eglamour is in her company. 'Tis true, for Friar Lawrence met them both As he in penance wandered through the forest; Him he knew well, and guessed that it was she, But, being masked, he was not sure of it. Besides, she did intend confession At Patrick's cell this even, and there she was not. These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence. Therefore, I pray you, stand not to discourse, But mount you presently and meet with me Upon the rising of the mountain foot That leads toward Mantua, whither they are fled. Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, and follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl That flies her fortune when it follows her. I'll after, more to be revenged on Eglamour Than for the love of reckless Silvia.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: And I will follow, more for Silvia's love Than hate of Eglamour that goes with her.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: And I will follow, more to cross that love Than hate for Silvia, that is gone for love.

scenes.location: Frontiers of Mantua. The forest

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: Come, come, be patient. We must bring you to our captain.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: A thousand more mischances than this one Have learned me how to brook this patiently.

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: Come, bring her away.

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

dialogues.speaker: Second Outlaw
dialogues.line: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us. But Moyses and Valerius follow him. Go thou with her to the west end of the wood; There is our captain. We'll follow him that's fled. The thicket is beset; he cannot 'scape.

dialogues.speaker: First Outlaw
dialogues.line: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave. Fear not; he bears an honourable mind And will not use a woman lawlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: O Valentine, this I endure for thee!

scenes.location: Another part of the forest

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: How use doth breed a habit in a man! This shadowy desert, unfrequented woods, I better brook than flourishing peopled towns. Here can I sit alone, unseen of any, And to the nightingale's complaining notes Tune my distresses and record my woes. O thou that dost inhabit in my breast, Leave not the mansion so long tenantless, Lest, growing ruinous, the building fall And leave no memory of what it was. Repair me with thy presence, Silvia; Thou gentle nymph, cherish thy forlorn swain. What hallowing and what stir is this today? These are my mates, that make their wills their law, Have some unhappy passenger in chase. They love me well; yet I have much to do To keep them from uncivil outrages. Withdraw thee, Valentine. Who's this comes here?

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Madam, this service I have done for you- Though you respect not aught your servant doth- To hazard life, and rescue you from him That would have forced your honour and your love. Vouchsafe me for my meed but one fair look; A smaller boon than this I cannot beg, And less than this, I am sure, you cannot give.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: How like a dream is this I see and hear! Love, lend me patience to forbear awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: O miserable, unhappy that I am!

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Unhappy were you, madam, ere I came; But by my coming I have made you happy.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: By thy approach thou mak'st me most unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: And me, when he approacheth to your presence.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: Had I been seized by a hungry lion, I would have been a breakfast to the beast Rather than have false Proteus rescue me. O heaven, be judge how I love Valentine, Whose life's as tender to me as my soul! And full as much, for more there cannot be, I do detest false perjured Proteus. Therefore be gone, solicit me no more.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: What dangerous action, stood it next to death, Would I not undergo for one calm look! O, 'tis the curse in love, and still approved, When women cannot love where they're beloved.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: When Proteus cannot love where he's beloved. Read over Julia's heart, thy first best love, For whose dear sake thou didst then rend thy faith Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths Descended into perjury to love me. Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou'dst two, And that's far worse than none; better have none Than plural faith, which is too much by one. Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: In love Who respects friend?

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: All men but Proteus.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words Can no way change you to a milder form, I'll woo you like a soldier, at arms' end, And love you 'gainst the nature of love-force ye.

dialogues.speaker: Silvia
dialogues.line: O heaven!

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: I'll force thee yield to my desire.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Ruffian, let go that rude uncivil touch, Thou friend of an ill fashion!

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Valentine!

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Thou common friend, that's without faith or love, For such is a friend now. Treacherous man, Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye Could have persuaded me. Now I dare not say I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me. Who should be trusted, when one's right hand Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus, I am sorry I must never trust thee more, But count the world a stranger for thy sake. The private wound is deepest. O time most accurst, 'Mongst all foes that a friend should be the worst!

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: My shame and guilt confounds me. Forgive me, Valentine; if hearty sorrow Be a sufficient ransom for offence, I tender 't here. I do as truly suffer As e'er I did commit.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Then I am paid, And once again I do receive thee honest. Who by repentance is not satisfied Is nor of heaven nor earth, for these are pleased; By penitence th' Eternal's wrath's appeased. And that my love may appear plain and free, All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: O me unhappy!

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Look to the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Why, boy! Why, wag! How now? What's the matter? Look up; speak.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: O good sir, my master charged me to deliver a ring to Madam Silvia, which out of my neglect was never done.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Where is that ring, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Here 'tis; this is it.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: How, let me see. Why, this is the ring I gave to Julia.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: O, cry you mercy, sir, I have mistook. This is the ring you sent to Silvia.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: But how cam'st thou by this ring? At my depart I gave this unto Julia.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: And Julia herself did give it me, And Julia herself have brought it hither.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: How? Julia?

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths And entertained 'em deeply in her heart. How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root! O Proteus, let this habit make thee blush. Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me Such an immodest raiment, if shame live In a disguise of love. It is the lesser blot, modesty finds, Women to change their shapes than men their minds.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Than men their minds! 'Tis true. O heaven, were man But constant, he were perfect. That one error Fills him with faults, makes him run through all th' sins; Inconstancy falls off ere it begins. What is in Silvia's face but I may spy More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Come, come, a hand from either. Let me be blest to make this happy close. 'Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.

dialogues.speaker: Proteus
dialogues.line: Bear witness, heaven, I have my wish for ever.

dialogues.speaker: Julia
dialogues.line: And I mine.

dialogues.speaker: Outlaws
dialogues.line: A prize, a prize, a prize!

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Forbear, forbear, I say! It is my lord the Duke. Your Grace is welcome to a man disgraced, Banished Valentine.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Sir Valentine!

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Yonder is Silvia, and Silvia's mine.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Thurio, give back, or else embrace thy death; Come not within the measure of my wrath. Do not name Silvia thine; if once again, Verona shall not hold thee. Here she stands; Take but possession of her with a touch- I dare thee but to breathe upon my love.

dialogues.speaker: Thurio
dialogues.line: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I. I hold him but a fool that will endanger His body for a girl that loves him not. I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: The more degenerate and base art thou To make such means for her as thou hast done, And leave her on such slight conditions.- Now, by the honour of my ancestry, I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine, And think thee worthy of an empress' love. Know then, I here forget all former griefs, Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again, Plead a new state in thy unrivalled merit, To which I thus subscribe: Sir Valentine, Thou art a gentleman, and well derived; Take thou thy Silvia, for thou hast deserved her.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I thank your Grace; the gift hath made me happy. I now beseech you, for your daughter's sake, To grant one boon that I shall ask of you.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I grant it for thine own, whate'er it be.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: These banished men, that I have kept withal, Are men endued with worthy qualities. Forgive them what they have committed here, And let them be recalled from their exile. They are reformed, civil, full of good, And fit for great employment, worthy lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Thou hast prevailed; I pardon them and thee. Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts. Come, let us go; we will include all jars With triumphs, mirth, and rare solemnity.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: And as we walk along, I dare be bold With our discourse to make your Grace to smile. What think you of this page, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: I warrant you, my lord, more grace than boy.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What mean you by that saying?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: Please you, I'll tell you as we pass along, That you will wonder what hath fortuned. Come, Proteus, 'tis your penance but to hear The story of your loves discovered. That done, our day of marriage shall be yours, One feast, one house, one mutual happiness.
